result.hateful_meaning: A black person, originating with the suit in a deck of cards.
A non-Japanese person. Shortened form of 'Gaikokujin' (person from another country).
A Native American person.

Szkop (plural szkopy) is another, similarly derogative term (original, now obsolete meaning: 'castrated ram', but see also the term Skopčák for Czech); during World War II, it was first used for German soldiers and later for any German.
A black person, used by Italians in US. It is a corruption of melanzane, the Italian word for eggplant.
A person of Latino descent, particularly a Mexican migrant laborer.
A person of Arab descent.
A black person.

An Asian, especially an enemy soldier of Asian descent. Its use as an ethnic slur has been traced to US Marines serving in the Philippines in the early 20th century. The earliest recorded example is dated 1920. It gained widespread notice as a result of the Korean and Vietnam wars.
A person of Latino descent, particularly a Mexican migrant laborer.

Pejorative term used in south of Mainland China and Hong Kong to denote a white man. Loosely translated as 'foreign devil;' more literally, might be 'ghost dude/bloke/guy/etc.' Gwei means 'ghost.' The color white is associated with ghosts in China. A lo is a regular guy (i.e. a fellow, a chap, or a bloke). Once a mark of xenophobia, the word is now in general, informal use but still considered derogatory.
A Hindu person with preceived black mannerisms.

[1] A Romani people. [2] Egyptians. These are variations of 'Gypsy', the most common word in English for people of Romani origin. 'Gypsy' is not in itself an ethnic slur but its usage is sometimes controversial.
An unassimilated or first-generation Italian, as identified by an American-born Italian.

[1] A Romani people. [2] Egyptians. These are variations of 'Gypsy', the most common word in English for people of Romani origin. 'Gypsy' is not in itself an ethnic slur but its usage is sometimes controversial.
A person of predominantly Caucasian ancestry with real or suspected African or Asian distant ancestry.

older person who support the views expressed by Polish conservative Catholic movement with its main representative being the media strictly connected with Father Tadeusz Rydzyk. This expression originated from the characteristic headgear worn by the stereotyped representatives of this circle.
[1] prostitute [2] whore; slut; bitch.
faggot (homosexual)
A word used in Mexico to denote a person of dark brown or black hair and of browner skin tones and/or Amerindian or Afro-Mexican origin
A Dutch person. Translates as 'cheese-head'.
Used by the Sinhala/Tamil majority to refer to a person of white caucasian or European origin. Generally refers all pale white-skinned people, and literal translation is 'white one'.

[1] A person from Jamaica, sometimes derogatory, referring to gang membership or low economic status. [2] In the UK, can be used broadly to denote a black person with gang association and/or engaging in criminal behavior.
In São Tomé and Príncipe, refers to descendants of Portuguese colonists and African slaves. Translates as "children of the land".
[1] In Brazil, a person of mixed indigenous and European parentage. [2] In Africa and Asia, any person of mixed parentage.
[1] In Brazil, a person of mixed indigenous and European parentage. [2] In Africa and Asia, any person of mixed parentage.
[1] Brazilian word for a person of mixed indigenous and European parentage. [2] Can also denote a culturally assimilated person of full Amerindian descent.
[1] Brazilian word for a person of mixed indigenous and European parentage. [2] Can also denote a culturally assimilated person of full Amerindian descent.
A person of mixed indigenous and African parentage.
A person of mixed indigenous and African parentage.
A person of mixed indigenous and African parentage. Similar origins as Spanish word "zambo".
Illegal boat person (Indian)
A black person. Jiggaboo or jigabo is from a Bantu verb tshikabo, meaning meek or servile.

Person of Mexican or Hispanic descent. This term is used by Sri Lankan diaspora living in USA.

A person of Mexican heritage who is partially or fully assimilated into American culture (literally, 'diluted, watered down (drink); undersized (clothing)').
A white person, from Pig Latin for 'foe.'
A person of German descent, from 'potato eater'.
Maori term for white New Zealanders, meaning 'white devil';
Derived from 'turnpike'. [1] An Irish person. [2] A gypsy. [3] An itinerant or vagrant lower-class or poor person.
Derived from 'turnpike'. [1] An Irish person. [2] A gypsy. [3] An itinerant or vagrant lower-class or poor person.
result.nonhateful_meaning: A person who prefers not to spend money

result.hateful_meaning: A black person.
[1] In the Caribbean, a non-Hispanic person of African origins. [2] In Spanish-speaking countries, a person from English or French areas of the Caribbean. [2] A follower of Afro-Latino music.

Australian Aboriginal person. Originally, this was simply an informal term for Aborigine, and was in fact used by Aboriginal people themselves until it started to be considered offensive in the 1950s. In remoter areas, Aboriginal people still often refer to themselves (quite neutrally) as Blackfellas (and whites as Whitefellas). Although Abo is still considered quite offensive by many, the pejorative boong is now more commonly used when the intent is to deliberately offend, as that word's status as an insult is unequivocal.
An African, used by white Rhodesians.
A black person, originated in the US in the 1950s.

A black person, especially a black child. More commonly used in states where alligators are found, particularly Florida. First used in the early 20th century, although some hypothesize the term originated in the late 19th century.
A black person
A black person.
Black children.
Found offensive, although it is a translation of the Chinese. It was used in the gold rush and railway-construction eras in western North America, when discrimination against Chinese was common.
A black person.
[1] A Chinese person trying to act like a black person. [2] A person of mixed black and Asian parentage.
[1] Derogatory term used in Mexico and elsewhere to denote a Chinese person. [2] Can also mean "friend" in Ghana or West Africa.
Person of Chinese descent.
A black person, from the black Muslims which invaded Europe during the Middle Ages.

result.hateful_meaning: A Caucasian.
Any person of South, Central and West Asian origin, especially referring to South Asian Muslims.
Used by Myanmar Buddhists to foment hate and exclusion from citizenship of Muslims. Calling them "Bengali" indicates they should be eliminated from Myanmar.

result.hateful_meaning: Referring to Muslims in Myanmar as an invasive species
Used by Mexicans to refer to other Mexicans, in contrast to Mexican-Americans.
A person of Latino descent, particularly a Mexican migrant laborer.
A Scientologist, referring to a passage about clam engrams in L. Ron Hubbard's 1952 book, What To Audit, later renamed The History Of Man
A Scientologist, referring to a passage about clam engrams in L. Ron Hubbard's 1952 book, What To Audit, later renamed The History Of Man

White on the inside and brown on the outside, like a Bounty chocolate bar. As with wigger, this is both a subcultural and ethnic slur. The immediate target is criticized for having the cultural values of a different ethnic group, with the implication that the ethnic group in question is bad or inferior. Coconut and Oreo are used in the same way.
A person of German descent.
A person of east-central European descent. Originally referred to those of Bohemian (now Czech Republic) descent. It was commonly used toward Ukrainian immigrants during the early 20th century.

[1] Australian aboriginal. Boong, pronounced with (like the vowel in bull), is related to the Australian English slang word bung, meaning dead; infected; or dysfunctional. From bung, to go bung 'Originally to die, then to break down, go bankrupt, cease to function [Ab. bong dead]'. Highly offensive. [2] In New Zealand, a Pacific Islander.
A disabled person.

Similar to the word sakslane ('German'), it was originally used for Germans, Saxons more precisely, but was later mostly used for German nobility in Estonia. Since then it has been offensively used for ethnic Estonian nobility. It is still sometimes used for Germans.
Person of Middle Eastern descent.

An Italian, Spaniard or Portuguese person, possibly derived from the Spanish name, 'Diego,' a corruption of the title Hidalgo (member of the Gentry, from Spanish > hijo de algo 'son of someone [important]' or the Sardinian language first person pronoun, dego)t.
An person of Asian descent.
Hispanic word for a person from the Dominican Republic, possibly from the Washington Heights area of New York City.
result.nonhateful_meaning: Spherical structures, particularly used in astronomical observatories

result.hateful_meaning: A person of German descent, from 'pighead'.
A person of East Indian origin.
An American. (Cockney rhyming slang: Septic tank - Yank)
A person of German descent.

A person of Hispanic descent. First recorded use in 1915. Theories include from 'no spik English' (and spiggoty from the Chicano no speak-o t'e English), but common belief is that it is an abbreviation of 'Hispanic'.
A black person, particularly a black woman, from the Ubangi people of Africa
A black person, particularly a black woman, from the Ubangi people of Africa
A non-Jewish woman. Derived from the Hebrew root Shin-Qof-Tzadei, meaning loathsome or abomination. Most commonly used to refer to a non-Jewish woman who is dating or married to a Jewish man.
A person of Samoan descent.
A term used for an African American, or other person of African descent.
[1] Civil war term for an educated (white collar) black person. [2] A person of Jewish descent, from the ashes in the vicinity of concentration camps.
Offensive term used in Northern Ireland to describe Protestants of British descent living in Northern Ireland.
result.nonhateful_meaning: Facial projection, particularly of a dog

result.hateful_meaning: A black person, originating from their working at shoe shine stands on urban streets or in bus and train station terminals.
